A design pattern is the re-usable form of a solution to a design problem. The idea was introduced by the architect Christopher Alexander and has been adapted for various other disciplines, particularly software engineering. == Details == An organized collection of design patterns that relate to a particular field is called a pattern language. This language gives a common terminology for discussing the situations designers are faced with. The elements of this language are entities called patterns. Each pattern describes a problem that occurs over and over again in our environment, and then describes the core of the solution to that problem, in such a way that you can use this solution a million times over, without ever doing it the same way twice. Documenting a pattern requires explaining why a particular situation causes problems, and how the components of the pattern relate to each other to give the solution. Christopher Alexander describes common design problems as arising from "conflicting forces"—such as the conflict between wanting a room to be sunny and wanting it not to overheat on summer afternoons. A pattern would not tell the designer how many windows to put in the room; instead, it would propose a set of values to guide the designer toward a decision that is best for their particular application. Alexander, for example, suggests that enough windows should be included to direct light all around the room. He considers this a good solution because he believes it increases the enjoyment of the room by its occupants. Other authors might come to different conclusions, if they place higher value on heating costs, or material costs. These values, used by the pattern's author to determine which solution is "best", must also be documented within the pattern. Pattern documentation should also explain when it is applicable. Since two houses may be very different from one another, a design pattern for houses must be broad enough to apply to both of them, but not so vague that it doesn't help the designer make decisions. The range of situations in which a pattern can be used is called its context. Some examples might be "all houses", "all two-story houses", or "all places where people spend time". For instance, in Christopher Alexander's work, bus stops and waiting rooms in a surgery center are both within the context for the pattern "A PLACE TO WAIT". == Examples == Software design pattern, in software design Architectural pattern, for software architecture Interaction design pattern, used in interaction design / human–computer interaction Pedagogical patterns, in teaching Pattern gardening, in gardening Business models also have design patterns. See Business model § Examples. == See also == Style guide Design paradigm Anti-pattern Dark pattern == References == == Further reading ==

items.question: According to Alexander, why is it a good solution to include enough windows to direct light all around a room?
items.answer: He believes it increases the enjoyment of the room by its occupants.

items.question: In which field are pedagogical patterns utilized?
items.answer: Pedagogical patterns are used in teaching.

items.question: Who first introduced the idea of a design pattern?
items.answer: The architect Christopher Alexander first introduced the idea of a design pattern.

items.question: According to the provided text, what were Christopher Alexander's key contributions to the concept of design patterns?
items.answer: Christopher Alexander introduced the idea of a design pattern as a reusable solution to a design problem. He also described common design problems as arising from "conflicting forces," such as wanting a room to be sunny without it overheating. Furthermore, he illustrated that a pattern should guide a designer with a set of values rather than rigid instructions; for example, he suggested including enough windows to direct light all around a room, valuing the occupants' enjoyment.

items.question: What is the context of a design pattern, and can you provide an example of a pattern and its context, as well as another field where design patterns are used?
items.answer: The context of a design pattern is the range of situations in which it can be used. For example, Christopher Alexander's pattern "A PLACE TO WAIT" has a context that includes both bus stops and waiting rooms in a surgery center. Besides architecture, design patterns are also used in fields like software design, teaching, and gardening.

items.question: What are the essential components that should be documented for a design pattern?
items.answer: A design pattern's documentation must describe the recurring problem it solves, which often arises from "conflicting forces." It must also explain the core of the solution and how its components interrelate. The documentation should include the values the author used to determine the "best" solution, as well as the pattern's context, which is the range of situations where it can be applied.
